SECRET. I understand that you would like an expression of our views on the subject of General Hurley's proposed visit to India, mentioned in Washington telegram No.4854, of which a copy was sent to Harrison on October 2nd. Apart from the consideration that we should be doubtful about giving facilities to Hurley which we did not offer to Wendell Willkie, we feel that so much depends on what the situation in India will be like at the time when Hurley is considering his visit, and on the character of the United States representative in New Delhi at the time, that at present we should find it hard to express an opinion on the desirability of the visit. We should not wish therefore to disagree with any views which the Viceroy might hold. The attached extract from a Personality Report on General Hurley made by our Embassy in 1939 is the latest impression of him that we have. titleInfo.title: 'Ext 5697/42 General Hurley, USA Minister to New Zealand: tour of Middle East, Russia, etc'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 14; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence and telegrams from the Government of India, External Department, the Foreign Office, the Secretary of State for India, the British Minister of State in Cairo, and the British Embassy in Washington, regarding a tour conducted by General Hurley (USA Minister to New Zealand) in support of the development of a war strategy for the Pacific. Hurley visited London and subsequently toured Egypt, Syria, Persia, Iraq, and Russia, before travelling to Australia and New Zealand.
